newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine business upbeat about S&P upgrade.
newsitem.headline: Argentine business upbeat about S&P upgrade.

text.p: Argentine businessmen Thursday welcomed a credit rating upgrade for Argentina by Standard and Poor's, saying it not only improved financial conditions for the country but also for corporations.

"It is a very important signal," Juan Bautista Ordonez, Communications manager of builders Group Roggio, told Reuters. "Any company in search of funds will get a lower rate abroad as a consequence of the fall in country risk."
S&P said Wednesday it was raising Argentina's long-term foreign currency debt rating to BB from BB-.

"It is a more realistic rating," the head of Argentina's Chamber of Exporters Enrique Mantilla said. He added the market had already discounted the announcement but it was still a good sign for the broader public.

Claudio Armada, head of Investor Relations at oil and energy holding CAPSA, said the new rating would prompt more international institutions to lend more funds not only to Argentina but also to Argentine companies.
Bank executives said the upgrade would lower borrowing costs, attract more investment and improve confidence.

"This could imply larger investments in the markets, easier access to international credit for Argentine firms and more confidence in the economy in general," said Ruben Beraja, head of the Association of Argentine Public and Private Banks.
The head of Argentina's Chamber of Mining Businessmen, Jorge Fillol Casas said his group was "very happy with this initiative and expects foreign investments will keep flowing to the country."
